snippet: Ashraf Ghani said that the C.I.A. abuses “violated all accepted norms of human rights in the world,” adding his name to the global reaction of shock, anger and cynicism that had swelled over the past 24 hours.
abstract: Afghan Pres Ashraf Ghani expresses astonishment at revelations of Central Intelligence Agency torture in his country and elsewhere, adding to growing worldwide reaction of shock, anger and cynicism; Prince Zeid Ra’ad Zeid al-Hussein, United Nations high commissioner for human rights, praises openness of report, saying it removes ability of some countries to continue denying they practice torture.

byline.original: By JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN and RICK GLADSTONE
byline.contributor: Joseph Goldstein reported from Kabul, and Rick Gladstone from New York. Reporting was contributed by Somini Sengupta from the United Nations; Anne Barnard from Beirut, Lebanon; Joanna Berendt from Warsaw; and Rukmini Callimachi from Istanbul.

lead_paragraph: Ashraf Ghani said that the C.I.A. abuses “violated all accepted norms of human rights in the world,” adding his name to the global reaction of shock, anger and cynicism that had swelled over the past 24 hours.

headline.main: Afghan Leader Expresses Shock at Torture Revelations
headline.print_headline: Some Praise for Openness Amid Anger at Report

keywords.value: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
keywords.name: subject
